item.title: Life Expectancy over Time
item.description: In the first blog, we look at the general trend of life expectancy over the time and its distribuitons. From the figure below, we have a general trend (e.g., increasing ) for life expectancy across time, this trend is somewhat linear. library(tidyverse) data = read.csv("../../../raw_data/08_gap-every-five-years.tsv", sep = "\t") head(data) ## country continent year lifeExp pop gdpPercap ## 1 Afghanistan Asia 1952 28.801 8425333 779.4453 ## 2 Afghanistan Asia 1957 30.

item.title: Life Expectancy over Time by Continent
item.description: In the last blog, we find the evidence that there should be a relationship between life expectancy and continent, in this blog, we will check it. Firstly, we will visualize the relationship between life expectancy and year by varying the continents. library(tidyverse) library(stargazer) data = read.csv("../../../raw_data/08_gap-every-five-years.tsv", sep = "\t") ols = lm(lifeExp ~ year, data) data$residulas = ols$residuals data %>% ggplot(aes(y = lifeExp, x = year, color = continent)) + geom_point() + stat_smooth(method = "lm", col = "red") + facet_wrap(vars(continent), scales = "free") + theme(legend.

item.title: Life Expectancy: regresion analysis
item.description: From the visualization in last blog, we expect a linear trend of life expectancy over the time. Is our assumption right? In this blog, we will check this intuition statistically. we formulate a linear model as following: \[\hat{\text{lifeExp}_i} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 * \text{year}_i\] The estimates of this linear regression model is shown in table below: library(tidyverse) library(stargazer) data = read.csv("../../../raw_data/08_gap-every-five-years.tsv", sep = "\t") ols = lm(lifeExp ~ year, data) stargazer(ols, type ="html") Dependent variable: lifeExp year 0.
